abstract.p: Frequency error, non-ideal channel estimation (CE) and inefficient seamless road side unit (RSU) service are critical issues occurring in conventional systems that are completely specified by current IEEE 802.11p standards. This study investigates novel techniques for achieving accurate frequency offset compensation and effective CE and RSU selection for handover in signal-overlapping areas. Recently, communications using data-aided orthogonal frequency-division multiplexing (DA-OFDM), such as pseudo-random-postfix OFDM and time-domain-synchronous OFDM (TDS-OFDM), have been actively studied because of their higher effectiveness, efficiency and better transmission quality. This study consists of three parts: (i) derivation of the maximum likelihood estimation for DA-OFDM, (ii) design of an accurate RSU selection scheme and (iii) implementation of a superior TD CE technique. Performance comparisons between the conventional and the proposed techniques are conducted through comprehensive computer simulations.

sec.title: Intelligent transportation system (ITS) history and its application
sec.p: ITS applications have generally been classified into three main categories in terms of their functionalities: safety, efficiency and comfort/value-added applications. These applications are well classified in [1]. As the markets for telematics and the need for safety-related applications have expanded significantly in recent years, automotive electronics are becoming more and more important. Advanced wireless communication technology actually grows momentum to ITS realisations.

The most famous vehicular communication related projects around the world are also described in [2]. Most of these research projects are part of the vehicular ad-hoc network (VANET). These research projects use conventional IEEE 802.11a systems to study the emulation environments.

The dedicated short range communication (DSRC) band occupies 75 MHz in the 5.850â5.925 GHz range. It was regulated by the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) in the United States to improve traveller safety, decrease the possibility of traffic congestion, to facilitate the reduction of air pollution and to help conserve vital fossil fuels [3]. The DSRC communication modes can be divided into two types: vehicle to infrastructure (V2I) and vehicle to vehicle (V2V). The entire DSRC spectrum is equally partitioned into seven channels, each with a 10 MHz bandwidth. There are four service channels (SCHs), one control channel (CCH) and two special-usage channels. DSRC is capable of exchanging data at a high rate between either a mobile or a stationary vehicle where an on-board unit (OBU) is located and stationary road side units (RSUs) mounted on structures along roadways or through hand-held devices.

sec.title: Orthogonal frequency-division multiplexing (OFDM)-based ITS system
sec.p:
To date, the first standardised vehicular communication standard is IEEE 802.11p [4]. IEEE 802.11p forms the wireless access standard in wireless access in vehicular environments (WAVE) in conjunction with the IEEE 1609.x and is a new variant of the IEEE 802.11 family. The IEEE 802.11p physical (PHY) layer and medium access control (MAC) layer specifications are based on the IEEE 802.11a, and it is used as the framework for DSRC to support inter-vehicle communication and ITS applications. In IEEE 802.11p, the SCHs, which are SCHs created for the purpose of avoiding or mitigating vehicle accidents and are also capable of real-time multimedia communications, operate at approximately 5.8 GHz. These ITS applications are usually reserved for the vehicle-to-infrastructure (V2I/I2V) communication mode. The parameters employed in the IEEE 802.11p are listed in Table 1. The IEEE 802.11p adopts the same PHY as the IEEE 802.11a, with the only exception being that a 10 MHz channel bandwidth is used in IEEE 802.11p. The challenges faced by an IEEE 802.11p system include wider coverage of operation, high-speed vehicles and extreme multipath environments. WAVE/DSRC is described in great detail in [5]. Table 1

Although IEEE 802.11p has already been standardised, there is no national-level standard announced to follow it. Many researchers studies addressed how to improve it or to propose new standards. In our previous field-trial research [6], packet loss is up to the level of 30% in high-speed V2I scenarios. Therefore a new system specification is highly desired. On the other hand, the most recent trend is to support vehicular communication networks with the assistance from mobile communication networks.

sec.title: Issues and related works
sec.p: In general, vehicular communication is very similar to mobile/cellular communication. The high-speed movement, large-scale service area and centralised control system are common to both scenarios. The ultimate goal for both mobile/cellular and vehicular communication is to build a large-scale service environment. In these conditions, vehicular communication designers could learn from the experiences of mobile communication designers. However, there are at least three main differences between vehicular communications and general-purpose mobile/cellular communications: for example, (i) machine-to-machine communications; (ii) recursive and specific data transmission (for a finite and small set of instructions); and (iii) requirements of low-complexity and high-stability transceiving algorithms. During the literature survey and analysis, two open issues were identified: the imperfect transceiver design in the current standard and the inefficient handover procedure.

The most comprehensive and complete standard for vehicular communication currently is IEEE 802.11p. However, not only is the current IEEE 802.11p inefficient at providing accurate channel estimation (CE) in a severely frequency-selective fading environment because of insufficient pilot density, but it also lacks rapid, effective PHY-layer handover schemes to help soft-handover in high mobility.

The transceiver design in the conventional IEEE 802.11p standard adopts a comb-type pilot to prevent the fading channel. Although a comb-type pilot arrangement can effectively combat fast fading effects, the pilot density in IEEE 802.11p is definitely insufficient to perform accurate CE in environments with long delay spreads. Therefore severe frequency selectivity becomes a troublesome issue [7]. On a severely multipath-faded channel, deep fades may occur between two neighbouring pilots. Although linear interpolation is applied in the frequency domain, which is considered to be the most popular method in an OFDM system, linear interpolation cannot accurately filter the data subchannel weights from these distantly separated pilots. Therefore the pilot density defined in the current IEEE 802.11p may be adequate in a line-of-sight (LOS) V2V scenario, but it is still insufficient in rich-scattering V2I or I2V environments.

To solve the pilot density insufficiency problem occurring in the current standard and to figure out the direction of the future national or international standard, several previous studies utilised midambles to assist the originally employed preambles for enhancing CE performance [8]. In these studies, the midambles worked like block-type pilots, which have previously been thoroughly investigated [8]. However, the use of midambles can improve CE, although transmission throughput is sacrificed. Based on the above reasoning, effective compensation for multipath effects is highly desired. To enhance CE performance in an OFDM communication, the use of pseudo-random-postfix OFDM (PRP-OFDM) communications [9] and time-domain synchronous OFDM (TDS-OFDM) communications [10], which arrange pseudo-random sequences into original guard intervals, has been proposed. These data-aided OFDMs (DA-OFDMs) are practical and also popularly employed in consumer products, such as in the Chinese digital terrestrial multimedia broadcast system transmission standard [10]. Our prior work has also applied these techniques to mobile OFDM communications [11, 12]. All of these previous studies employed pseudo-random sequences to perform TD CE. In addition, a TD CE method has been investigated for the application of the PRP-OFDM technique to the IEEE 802.11p applications [11, 12].

In contrast, TDS-OFDM technology is primarily applied in the digital broadcasting applications. Therefore it usually occupies a much wider band and employs a long training sequence (i.e. two PN sequences in self-prefix and postfix) to cascade to the OFDM symbol prefix. Although this design works well on wireless digital television broadcasting, these designs are definitely not suitable on a DSRC band that is much narrower than the wireless digital television band. This is the main reason why a vehicular communication-specific DA-OFDM has been designed.

The longer time required for currently existing handover procedures is another drawback, which renders them extremely difficult to utilise in safety-related applications. The IEEE 802.11a standard originally worked in an indoor environment where no cellular structure exists; thus, most relevant handover research is derived directly from conventional IEEE 802.11 techniques. The main approach of these studies is based on mobile Internet protocol (mobile IP) or cellular IP. However, mobile IP or cellular IP research is often aimed at data transmission or multimedia communications. As a result, very few high-mobility effects have been seriously considered. The handover procedure has been well illustrated in [13]. Meanwhile, a seamless communication service solution that can reduce the handover latency has also been proposed. The simulation in this paper is based on the transceiver works in an ideal condition, which can recognise the succeeding RSU instantaneously during the handover procedure; likewise the synchronisation and CE work perfectly.

In practice, a handover procedure consists of the following three steps: scanning, authentication and association. Most of the relevant research regarding handover in vehicular communication scenarios focuses on upper-layer authentication and association functions, such as [14, 15]. Unlike in mobile communications (e.g. third-generation partnership project (3GPP) long-term evolution (LTE)-A or mobile WiMAX), no previous work considered sector search (name derived from LTE-A), ranging (named from WiMAX) or handover procedures on the PHY transmission layer of the IEEE 802.11. Therefore currently rapid handover is still difficult to achieve. Apparently, rapid handover is highly desired for current vehicular communications because they are built according to IEEE 802.11 PHY.

A convincing experimental testbed for the IEEE 802.11 handover was proposed previously in [15]. In this research, the proposed handover method works on the MAC layer. The PHY scanning for a beacon is only used for estimating the signal strength from candidate access points surrounding the given mobile station (MS). Therefore in this scheme, the pre-handover procedure cannot be conducted. Subsequently, pre-handover was shown to function in the method proposed in [16]. However, this method also conducted handover on the upper layers.

In [17], an MAC protocol improvement for video streaming applications over VANETs is described. The RSU network topology of the simulation scenario is not continuous. If the PHY handover (especially soft-handover) technique is good enough, the application of the MAC protocol can be extended, improving the performance. In [18], a large-scale VANET scenario has been discussed. Several ideas in MAC that are addressed in [18], such as time synchronisation and decreasing the packet collisions, can be used to complement the proposed method in this paper. Moreover, Wu and Weng [14] proposed a new idea in which MS can obtain the RSUs location information with assistance from global positioning service (GPS) systems. The MS can begin to process the pre-handover at the pre-setup positions.

In view of the above concerns, the IEEE 802.11p frame structure has to be modified very slightly to significantly improve the PHY handover effectiveness of the IEEE 802.11p for the primary purpose of achieving a sufficiently rapid handover.

To solve the rapid handover and pre-handover issues, a somewhat classic research topic, synchronisation must be taken into account herein. In the current IEEE 802.11p standard, a short preamble can synchronise the receiving symbols through a series of training sequences. The synchronisation techniques used in communication systems have been developed for decades. One of the most useful and accurate methods for estimating timing and frequency offsets is the maximum-likelihood estimation (MLE). van de Beek et al. [19] proposed an efficient maximum-likelihood (ML) joint estimator of timing and frequency offsets by using a cyclic prefix (CP) in the data-frame. In general, a residual timing offset within the inter-symbol interference (ISI)-free range does not influence or degrade the system performance, but a frequency offset does. Therefore adequate timing synchronisation is easy to achieve [19]. The positioning techniques, such as the time-of-arrival method, require precise synchronisation between the transmitter and the receiver. In contrast, the RSU selection can also support vehicle localisation. In [20, 21], the vehicle location management methods have been addressed. However, these methods require knowledge of high-level packet data or GPS information. The RSU selection method proposed in this paper can help the OBU obtain location information from a few cooperative RSUs.

sec.title: Contribution
sec.p: In this paper, a practical IEEE 802.11p-like vehicular DA-OFDM transceiver architecture is proposed and thoroughly studied. This novel OFDM architecture for vehicular communication can accomplish better performance in synchronisation and CE than conventional CP OFDM systems. A modified ML estimation method that can use be applied on DA-OFDM has been addressed. Besides, a TD CE method that can work well in the overlap area is studied thoroughly, and a complete transceiver with the assistance from the proposed TD CE is verified in this paper. In addition, a novel, efficient PHY RSU selection scheme is proposed and thoroughly investigated in this paper. The proposed PHY RSU selection is based on the handover concepts employed in cellular communications in order to support high mobility. The proposed RSU selection can achieve remarkable improvements on a predictive handover mechanism, and it allows the OBUs to recognise which RSUs could provide satisfactory services.

These benefits will improve the transceiver performance, and stable transmission and faster handover and location services can also be realised based on the proposed techniques. In data transmission in high-speed trains [22], for example, the PHY improvement in this paper can enhance the MAC algorithm proposed in [22]. Tunnel safety communication, radio data system-traffic message channel (RDS-TMC) and real-time vehicle/driver monitoring are some examples of the possible applications. Moreover, cellular-vehicle communication is a very important future research topic that can be studied based on the achievements presented in this paper.

Section 2 of this paper briefly describes the operating scenario and system structure under scrutiny. In Section 3, the proposed RSU selection and synchronisation methods are explained. In Section 4, comparative computer simulations of IEEE 802.11p communications are presented. Finally, relevant comparisons and concluding remarks are presented in Section 5.

sec.title: RSU topology
sec.p:
The RSU topology adopted here is the mesh topology, which is illustrated in Fig. 1. Usually, a wireless band is partitioned into many channels, which are then exclusively allocated to individual cells such that each cell does not own channels whose spectra do not overlap with those of any other cell. The co-channel interference during sector search in a cellular network can therefore be assumed to be negligible. Unfortunately, an RSU could occasionally occupy the same channel band, particularly in a metropolitan setting with complex transportation systems, thus causing overcrowding of the radio spectra. WAVE service advertisement (WSA) works to provide the notifications of the services the RSU serves and what SCH(s) they are provided on (MAC layer) to users. Therefore WSAs from two neighbour RSUs are quite similar. To prevent mutual interference between two RSUs, time-division duplex is a well-developed idea that can be used to solve this problem. Meanwhile, the WSA is not the only message being sent in the CCH; there are several different control signals being sent after periodic WSAs. From this sequence, each WSA transmission interleaves with a WSA period, as shown in Fig. 1a, to satisfy most conditions. However, in some special conditions in which the street patterns are complex, more time slots are needed to separate the signals from different RSUs, as shown in Fig. 1b. Fig. 1

sec.title: RSU selection and handover
sec.p: High-mobility must be inherently taken into consideration for mobile communications but not for wireless local area networks (WLANs), for example, IEEE 802.11 a/b/g, for which, the common PHY is also exploited in IEEE 802.11p for vehicular communications. When IEEE 802.11p operates in the outdoor environment, the RSU selection and the handover must become significantly crucial issues as the result of high mobility and multiple RSUs, which were not taken into consideration for a WLAN. A usual handover process often consists of three steps: scanning, authentication and association. After the scanning process is completed by a MS or a vehicle, three sets of identification codes should be classified. They are called the active set, the candidate set and the neighbour (or monitored) set. The active set is also the service providing set at the current time. Signal-to-interference ratio (SIR) is often an effective indicator that is exploited for handover decisions, cell reselections and a few other PHY procedures and is therefore used as a coverage indicator for a given cell. SIR can be represented as Ec/I0, where Ec is the energy contained in one chip of the signal and I0 is the total effective interference with interference power spectrum density in the band. If Ec/I0 of any signal from other RSUs is detected higher than that required for serving as an effective ID code in the active set, the RSU will be classified to be a candidate set. If the Ec/I0 of any signal from other RSUs is lower than the required value set for serving as an ID code in the active set, the corresponding RSUs will be classified as a neighbour set.

In 3GPP LTE specifications, when user equipment (UE) moves between two cells, backward or predictive handover is used. In this type of handover, the source cell determines the target cell based on the measurement report and then, it queries the target cell whether it owns sufficient resources to serve the UE. Meanwhile, the target cell begins to prepare radio resources before the source cell handovers the UE to the target cell itself. As in mobile communications, the WAVE network also has a similar design. The CCH broadcasts WSA messages periodically and broadcasts urgent short messages occasionally. Therefore the OBU may receive WSA messages from different RSUs at the same time. When the OBU separates the received mixed signals, it can identify the WSA message with the highest power as being from the current RSU and the one with the second highest power as being from a candidate RSU. This procedure is called RSU selection.

Although an OBU has a current candidate RSU, the data flow is transmitted via the SCHs. Simultaneously, the CCH is still transmitting WSA messages periodically and transmitting urgent short messages occasionally. Meanwhile, synchronisation, CE and equalisation are conducted in order to reduce channel impairments. When the OBU enters a common area belonging to two serving RSUs, the handover procedure is processed successively. Handover information is currently packed into WSA message packets from the RSU to the OBU. This conventional arrangement means that an OBU cannot process an active handover or pre-synchronise to a successive RSU. Fortunately, if the DA-OFDM proposed here is employed with the assistance from training sequences arranged as symbol prefixes, the OBU can easily adopt these different training sequences to conduct active handover or pre-synchronisation.

sec.title: Transceiver structure
sec.p:
A DA-OFDM transceiver architecture is depicted in Fig. 2. As the ordinary OFDM tranceiver, the resultant signal at the modulator output is Sm,N. The optional signal mapping schemes, such as binary phase-shift keying (BPSK), quadrature phase-shift keying (QPSK), 16-QAM, and 64-QAM, are utilised in the transmission unit. xm,N is the modulation output of the source data stream Sm,N by an inverse discrete Fourier transform block modulation. The comb-type pilot symbols are inserted onto the given subcarriers for CE, which are located on the â 21st, â 7th, 7th and 21st subcarriers. Fig. 2
Proposed (uncoded) DA-OFDM transceiver structure

In Fig. 3, the symbol structure is depicted in detail. The preamble employed in the proposed technique is the same as that in the current IEEE 802.11p standard. Short preambles are used for time synchronisation and coarse CE. Long preambles are used for fine CE. It is thus assumed that the initial channel state can be estimated well after the preambles. However, the channel state may change with time. Therefore each symbol has to update the channel state and compensate for a timing and frequency offset iteratively on time. The transceiver design proposed in this paper will focus on synchronisation and CE on a symbol-by-symbol basis. The symbols after the preamble are a data symbol stream. The guard interval (GI) in the data symbol stream that is shown in Fig. 3 is designed to prevent inter-symbol interference (ISI). Usually, the GI in the data symbol stream is inserted in a CP; however, in DA-OFDM, training sequences pL are inserted as the prefix of each OFDM symbol. The Gold-sequence serves both as the RSU ID code and as the pre-synchronisation sequence, and it is assigned as shown in Table 2. Fig. 3
Transmission symbol structure

This will be described in further detail in the following section. At the receiving end, after the carrier frequency and the timing offset synchronisation, the compensated signal is estimated to determine the channel condition and to enable the equaliser to succeed. Then, the prefix is removed and the signal is fed into the block demodulator based on discrete Fourier transform (DFT).

As mentioned in the first section, the impact of channel interference on vehicle communications fluctuates rapidly and unpredictably. As a result, the fading channel is referred to as a rapidly time-varying channel. Path loss is a large-scale fading, which comes from the strength of the radio signal getting weak. Path loss and shadowing effects are typically dealt with by automatic power control or diversity techniques. A propagation conveying LOS is often modelled as a Rician distribution, whereas a non-LOS is often modelled as a Rayleigh distribution model. In addition, the system performance evaluation in this paper adopts a small-scale fading model that was measured and characterised by the IEEE 802.11 working group at the Georgia Institute of Technology [24]. sec.title: Synchronisation
sec.p: In the current IEEE 802.11p standard, the timing offset can be estimated by transmitting a series of training sequences in a short preamble. By several conventional methods [19, 25, 26], the timing offset can be recovered well. In fact, in the OFDM system, a time offset usually cannot significantly change the received signal quality if the right timing instant still falls in the ISI-free region. Inherently, a carrier frequency offset (CFO) leads to inter-carrier interference (ICI) and it can thus significantly degrade performance on signal detection.

The CFO in the OFDM system not only attenuates the amplitude of the receiving signal but also leads to ICI, which can destroy the orthogonality of the subcarriers [26]. van de Beek et al. also proposed a useful ML estimation method for synchronisation. The conventional Beek's method uses the tail data to process ML algorithm with CP. However, the DA-OFDM has no embedded CP. DA-OFDM is also different with TDS-OFDM. Unlike TDS-OFDM, DA-OFDM cannot use its long training sequence being inserted in the prefix to process synchronisation. In this circumstance, the modified BeekÃ´s ML estimation is proposed. In this method, a redundancy buffer is needed. Although the proposed method needs more memory than the conventional standard, the remarkable improvement on performance is worth.

sec.title: Channel estimation
sec.p: Specified in the current IEEE 802.11p standard, four pilots are allocated in an OFDM block and they are exploited for the sake of CE. The four pilots are retained in the proposed technique. Thus, conventional CE methods (e.g. linear interpolation) must still be used. Sometimes, a conventional CE method will adopt a channel tracking method to enhance performance. The channel tracking method proposed previously [27] used the FD channel state information which was estimated in the preamble to be the reference states and uses pilots to measure the difference between the on-time channel states and the reference states. The reference states can then be modified to match the on-time channel states. This scheme could reduce the inaccuracy of linear interpolation.

The proposed CE method is based on our previous research [11, 12]. The main idea of our proposed method is TD CE, which is used to analyse the received training sequence to obtain the channel impulse response (CIR). As shown in Fig. 2, the mth receive vector r is the combination of the prefix vector rm,L, and the data stream vector rm,N. As shown in Fig. 2, L is the length of the prefix and N is the length of the FFT size. Therefore the IBI must be removed by means of the following self-interference-cancellation (SIC) method because it can be regenerated by the knowledge of pre-determined training sequence. Accordingly, the proposed technique employs the pre-DFT TD samples after OLA with SIC, that is $${\bi r^{\prime \prime}}_{m\comma N} = \left\{{\matrix{ {{\bi r^{\prime}}_{m\comma N} - \sum\limits_{i = 1}^n \widehat{\bi h}_{m\comma i} {\bi p}_{L\comma n - i} } & {n = 1\comma \; 2\comma \; \ldots \comma \; \displaystyle{L \over 2}} \cr {{\bi r^{\prime}}_{m\comma N} } & {n = \displaystyle{L \over 2} + 1\comma \; \ldots \comma \; N} \cr } } \right.$$râ²â²m,N=râ²m,Nââi=1nh^m,ipL,nâin=1,2,â¦,L2râ²m,Nn=L2+1,â¦,N Thus, the compensate received signal in frequency form ${\bi R}_{m,N} = {\rm DFT}\left\{ {{\bi r}_{m,N} } \right\}$Rm,N=DFTrm,N. By taking advantage of the fact that (MHM)â 1MH can be pre-calculated and pre-stored, the complexity of the TD LS channel estimator may be less than the FD comb-type pilot interpolation.

sec.title: RSU selection
sec.p: The DA-OFDM can be adopted to enhance rapid RSU identification (ID). The Gold-sequence inserted in the prefix also works as RSU ID; then, by detecting and analysing the receiving symbols, the OBU can scan all candidate RSUs in an overlapped area. This procedure is similar to cell/sector search in mobile/cellular communications, such as LTE-A or WiMAX-2. In this paper, we focus on how an OBU can use a training sequence to determine which RSU is the main service provider and which RSU is the most likely candidate to be the next service provider. This particular RSU candidate scanning procedure can be called RSU selection. Once an OBU confirms the following RSU, the OBU can also realise its location, then use the information to update the information which is generated from [20, 21].

As shown in Fig. 5, when a vehicle enters into an overlapping area, it will sense a signal that is a combination of the signals coming from RSU 1 and RSU 2. Point A is the threshold at which the signal strength can be detected by the OBU. Point B is the action point to start handover. As a result, the RSU selection should be completed between points A and B. Fig. 5
RSU selection (schematic diagram)

The RSU selection method is first addressed in this paper and has not been applied to vehicular communication networks yet. Therefore we have to evaluate the probability of a false decision for this new scheme. The decision scheme is described as follows:
First, the synchronisation procedure is assumed to be well processed. Then, the OBU will buffer a WSA packet with several data symbols.
Second, n symbols are cumulated and normalised to be a reference symbol unit. This procedure results in noise reduction. This procedure is repeated to obtain k reference symbol units.

Finally, based on Fig. 1, there might be three candidate RSUs that use different RSU IDs. After the MLE procedure, three different values of Î³k will be obtained. By ordering these estimates of Î³k, the most probable sequence adopted by the successive RSUs can be realised. Obviously, more accuracy could be obtained for k values greater than unity.

The RSU selection algorithm is described by the pseudocode in Algorithm 1 (see Fig. 6). Fig. 6
Algorithm 1: RSU selection

sec.title: Simulation and discussion
sec.p: Three simulations were conducted and presented in this paper: the probability of a false decision during RSU selection, MSE for synchronisation and bit error rate (BER) for CE. Simulation parameters for the IEEE 802.11p standard are listed in Table 1, and the Gold-sequence used in the proposed DA-OFDM is listed in Table 3. Table 3 lists the channel conditions. The simulation scenario for RSU selection is performed as a vehicle through one RSU to another. Moreover, there are three possible target service areas that are controlled by three different RSUs. These three RSUs all broadcast their own signal. The simulation scenario for synchronisation and CE involves testing the performance of the transceiver. In this scenario, the OBU transceiver will receive symbol streams from the RSU.

During RSU selection, the procedure will accumulate n symbols, normalise them to be a reference symbol unit and use reference symbol units to determine the candidate RSU. Therefore the evaluation metric is the probability of a false decision for different n and k; n = 10 and k = 1, 4. The path loss model adopted for this simulation is a log-normal distributed model.

For synchronisation, the frequency offset was set in this simulation at 20 ppm of the carrier frequency. The evaluation metric was the mean-square error (MSE). The synchronisation techniques compared in this paper are the conventional MLE method, which was proposed in [19], and our proposed method. In the conventional MLE method, the CP was used to obtain the phase shift. In our proposed method, the DA prefix was used to estimate the phase shift.

For the comparison of CE techniques, this paper compared the BER performances of the conventional CP-OFDM and the proposed technique using different signal-to-noise ratio (SNRs) under the same channel conditions. The modulation type was QPSK and the packet length was two preambles (a short preamble and long preamble) with either 25 data symbols. The speeds and environments tested in the paper were 120 km/h to represent urban and rural environments and 140 km/h to represent the expressway [24]. All simulations were transmitted for 10 s. The CE techniques compared in this paper were conventional methods using a pilot with linear interpolation. The proposed method will use our proposed TD LS CE technique. Simultaneously, the CE performance in the overlap area was also evaluated. Assuming that the overlap area between two RSUs is 1 m long, we observe the CE performance from the point a vehicle enters the overlap area to the handover point. Within this area, the OBU in the vehicle receives signals from both RSUs. In this simulation, the path loss is defined using a log-distance model, and the two RSUs transmit interactively.

Shown in Fig. 7 are the rates of false decisions on different SNR values. It can be observed that the performance of the proposed RSU selection was evaluated. Lower rates of false decisions will help the OBU catch the following RSU with improved accuracy. The OBU can also synchronise the following RSU signal before a handover, which enables a soft-handover. Even at very low SNRs, the false decision probability was still lower than 10â 2. If the reference symbol units k is increased from 1 to 4, the improvement in performance will also be higher. This is because the channel condition is sometimes really severe for a short period, while multiple time decisions are used to avoid an occasional misjudgment. Fig. 7
False decision probability by using DA prefix

Fig. 8 shows the MSEs obtained using the proposed technique and conventional technique compared here. It was observed that the proposed method resulted in a remarkable improvement. Compared with the conventional MLE, the MSEs showed that the proposed method had more than a 40â50% improvement in synchronisation. This improvement results from the inclusion of training sequences in the DA-OFDM which is better than the use of CPs. This result also proves that the DA-OFDM is a practical architecture for vehicular communication networks. In addition, the proposed MLE and conventional MLE are actually similar, and therefore it enables the existing transceiver unit to adapt easily to the new design. Fig. 8
Normalised MSE of different synchronisation techniques

As shown in Fig. 9, comparisons of CE techniques also suggest that the proposed method can recover a rapidly fluctuating fading channel. Furthermore, the proposed method is approximately 30% better than the conventional methods. Based on the previous three simulation results, we believe that the proposed transceiver can be one of the strong candidates in next-generation vehicular communication systems, especially because it confirms that the proposed technique can afford safety-related ITS applications. Fig. 9
BER of different channel estimation techniques

Fig. 10 shows the transmission status of the conventional and the proposed method in the overlap area. The effective transmission status of the proposed method is more stable than that of the conventional method. Developing a more stable transmission condition during the handover process is a basic requirement for approaching seamless transmission. Although the proposed method requires more memory than the conventional standard to buffer the training sequence, the remarkable improvement in performance is worth the cost. The performance was benchmarked with the MATLAB tic-toc method, and multiple simulation times were averaged to minimise statistical deviations. The proposed DA-OFDM will increase the computation time by 0.85% over the conventional CP-OFDM. Fig. 10
Jitter of effective transmission amount different channel estimation techniques in overlap area (SNR = 10)

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: This paper proposed a practical DA-OFDM transceiver for vehicular communications. In addition, a new RSU selection technique was studied. An overall design of the transceiver structure, which can be adopted in current IEEE 802.11p specifications, was investigated. The proposed technique assisted from the Gold-sequence as a prefix exhibits more precise estimations and therefore can achieve lower error probabilities. This paper is focused on transceiving techniques, and so all the simulations are based on one vehicle to one RSU and one vehicle to multiple RSUs. The multi-vehicle and large data simulation should be adopted as the simulation scenario for real and practical applications. In our survey, RDS-TMC is a good simulation scenario. The advantages of the proposed technique have been verified by means of extensive computer simulations.
